Dear Andrea Melendrez:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Please review the
enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In the event
that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager at 616-552-3662.
Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4131 Compliance with child protection law;
Section development of plan required.
Description (1) The licensee shall develop and implement a written plan to
assure compliance with the child protection law, 1975 PA 238,
MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Chief Administrator did not report suspected child abuse/ neglect
to the appropriate government agency within 24 hours.
Investigation I was assigned this investigation on 6/12/23.
I contacted Complainant via phone. He does not work at the
facility but said Staff 4 informed him that one staff at the facility
twisted a child’s ear and another staff left bruises on a second
child on 5/27/23. Complainant said Chief Administrator (CA) was
aware of the incidents but did not report them, so he reported
them to the appropriate government agency on 5/30/23.
According to MISACWIS, CA did report one of the two incidents
on 5/31/23. Consultant 2 and Government Worker 1 were
assigned to investigate those allegations.
On 6/12/23, I arrived at the facility unannounced and interviewed
Staff 1, 2 and 3 separately. All said they were trained on and
understood the Child Protection Law. None had ever suspected
abuse at the facility.
I reviewed the agency’s Child Protection Law policy. The policy is
consistent with the law and instructs staff to report all suspected
abuse/neglect directly to the government agency.
I collaborated with Consultant 2. She had already determined in
SIR 2023C0000500 that multiple staff witnessed potentially
abusive events and failed to report them to the government
agency within 24 hours. SIR 2023C0000500 cited the agency for
failure to comply with the Child Protection Law.
Analysis Failure to report suspected child abuse was investigated by
Consultant 2 and cited in SIR 2023C0000500. It was determined
multiple staff witnessed potentially abusive events and failed to
report them to the appropriate government agency within 24
hours. The agency was cited for R 400.4131 Child Protection
2

Law. Therefore, the agency is not being cited again for the same
incidents.
CONSULTATION
I observed the phone list and contact number for MDHHS
Centralized Intake posted in the staff office. I suggested CA label
the number “Children’s Protective Services” since staff may not
know it by the name of MDHHS Centralized Intake.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED (cited in 2023C0000500)
Rule Code & Rule 400.4116 Chief administrator; responsibilities.
Section (1) An agency shall assign the chief administrator responsibility for
Description the onsite day-to-day operation of the institution and for ensuring
compliance with these rules.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Chief Administrator did not discipline, terminate, or place staff on
administrative leave under investigation for suspected
abuse/neglect.
Investigation It was Complainant’s opinion that CA took too much time to
address the staff with pending abuse allegations. He stated, “The
employees didn’t get disciplined or terminated until I called the
government agency. CA should have moved quicker. She took
four days. As of now, I’m still not sure if they (staff) were
(disciplined/terminated) or not. They (staff) shouldn’t just be on
restrictions.”
I coordinated with Consultant 2 and Government Worker 1
regarding the safety/separation plans implemented for the three
staff under investigation. For incidents on 5/27/23 Consultant 2
indicated Former Staff 1 continued to work until she resigned on
5/31/23 and Manager of Compliance (non-regulated position) told
her the other two staff were working on the unit, but they would
not be alone with children or restrain any child. On 6/6/23,
Consultant 2 met with Manager of Compliance and Director of
Operations (another non-regulated position) and strongly
recommended the remaining two staff be placed on administrative
leave pending the outcome of the investigation. Finally, on 6/8/23
the facility placed Staff 6 on administrative leave, but Former Staff
2 continued to work until she resigned on her own on 6/14/23.
3

Analysis Licensing rules do not prohibit staff under investigation from
working. However, for the protection of both parties, it is general
practice at child caring institutions to separate the staff from the
alleged child victims pending the outcome of the investigation.
The initial safety/separation plans implemented were unrealistic,
unsafe and not timely. It is unsafe and unfair to coworkers to
allow certain staff to work with children while they are not allowed
to restrain in emergencies. It is unrealistic to have staff persons
working on a unit with structural blind spots and commit that they
will not be alone with a child. Thirdly, safety/separation plans
were not done timely. They were implemented days and weeks
after the incidents and developed by individuals in unregulated
positions who do not work in the facility or directly with the staff or
children involved.
CA is responsible for the day-to-day operations at the facility. She
did not develop sufficient or timely safety/separation plans for
Former Staff 1 & 2 or Staff 6. The staff continued to work with the
identified child victims while they were being investigated for
alleged abuse. Those investigations were completed on 6/22/23.
While the identified staff persons were not substantiated by the
government agency for child abuse, all three were placed on the
“confirmed” list, meaning they were deemed unsafe to work with
children.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Rule Code & Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation/ Chief Administrator does not respond to important
Additional communications from staff.
Findings
Investigation Complainant said CA did not answer an important call from Staff 4
and did not return the call.
4

I left voice message for Staff 4 on 6/14/23 and 6/22/23. As of
6/26/23, I have been unable to connect with her.
I asked CA who the staff can contact for direction afterhours and
on weekends and holidays. She said if she is unavailable, they
can call Director of Operations (non-regulated position) or
Licensee Designee. For medical concerns, staff can contact
Nurse who is available 24/7.
I reviewed the agency’s Access to Administrator policy. It
indicates the Licensee Designee (LD) is available and reachable
via cell phone 24/7 to all employees and any governing body. The
cell numbers of CA and LD were posted in the staff office.
ADDITIONAL FINDING
Throughout the course of this investigation, I learned that CA is
frequently expected to perform the duties of three regulated
positions. She works as chief administrator, direct care staff and
supervisor of direct care staff simultaneously which is not doable.
CA said a direct care staff was recently promoted to Team Leader.
I checked his resume and transcripts, and Team Leader does
qualify as a Supervisor of Direct Care Staff.
Direct Care Staff 1, 2, and 3 said they were aware of Team
Leader. However, they did not recognize him as a supervisor but
instead, referred to CA as their direct supervisor.
I interviewed CA at the facility on 6/12/23. Due to short staffing,
she said she is working as the CA, the supervisor and direct care
staff. I asked how many supervisors work at the facility. CA said
Team Leader works afternoon shift on weekdays and 14 hours a
day every other weekend. CA works as the Supervisor on
weekdays and there is no midnight shift supervisor.
I asked about the Social Service Worker at the facility. CA said
Social Service Worker comes to the facility once a week for team
meetings.
I asked about the Social Service Supervisor. CA said Social
Service Supervisor’s office is located off-site and that she never
comes to the facility.
I asked who decides whether to admit new children and if those
children are appropriate for admission. CA said the Licensee
Designee who works off-site decides which children to admit and
5

how many, based on staffing. I asked if the facility has ever been
fully staffed with administrative, supervisory, social service, and
direct care staff. She said since they opened in 2022. there was
never a time when she has not had to perform multiple roles.
I attempted to interview Team Leader via phone on 6/14/23. As of
6/26/23, Team Leader did not return my call.
On 6/22/23 I emailed Licensee Designee requesting the facility’s
organizational chart. It showed individuals in positions of Licensee
Designee, Chief Administrator and 13 Direct Care Staff. One of
those staff was placed on the “confirmed” list on 6/22/23 and
another is on leave pending the outcome of investigation SIR
2023C0000559, leaving 11 Direct Care Staff to cover three shifts.
There were no Supervisors of Direct Care Staff listed on the chart
and no empty Supervisor vacancies. I brought it to the attention of
Licensee Designee via email that there are no supervisors and
that individuals covering as Supervisors do not count as direct
care staff in the 2:1 ratio unless the supervisor is specified as and
only working that shift as direct care staff.
Analysis Regarding the allegation that the CA does not respond to
important calls, the agency is found in compliance as there are
emergency numbers available to staff outside of regular business
hours.
The agency does not have a sufficient number of supervisory or
direct care staff to perform the prescribed functions required by
licensing rules.
On weekdays, CA works two or three different regulated positions
simultaneously and is the primary person on-call on afternoons,
nights, weekends, and holidays. This is unacceptable and
unsustainable.
There is one afternoon shift Team Leader/Supervisor who was
recently assumed the position. Team Leader is also one of the
staff identified by Consultant 2 as failing to report suspected
abuse in SIR 2023C0000500. It is likely the facility routinely
counts Team Leader/Supervisor in the staffing ratio.
Prior to Team Leader’s promotion, CA said she was the only
Supervisor at the facility. She also covers for Direct Care Staff
when staffing is short. Currently the facility does not have a
sufficient number of supervisors to run a 24/7 operation or a
6

sufficient number of direct care staff to consistently run a ratio of 1
staff for every 2 children.
Conclusion REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio
Section (1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-to-child
Description ratio formula for direct care workers. If a child caring institution is
contracted by the department to care for youth, the facility will
follow its contracted ratio.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Additional Chief Administrator indicated the facility has a staff-to-resident
Findings: ratio of 1:2. On 6/12/23, while I was at the facility, Chief
Administrator was working as direct care staff and left two staff on
the unit with six youth.
Investigation According to CA, the facility’s policy indicates a ratio of 1:2 staff to
youth is maintained during waking hours. CA did not know if the
ratio was set by the MDHHS contractor or if the agency set it on
their own.
On 6/12/23, CA said there were six youth on the unit being
monitored by herself and two direct care staff. CA sat with me in
the conference room for approximately an hour leaving the unit
out of ratio. While working as direct care staff, CA admitted she
sometimes leaves the unit to do administrative and supervisory
tasks but counts herself in the ratio.
I interviewed Staff 5 on 6/23/23 via phone. She works midnight
shifts from 10pm – 9am. Staff 5 expressed concerns about the
facility being short-staffed, particularly in the mornings between
7:30am – 9am when the children are waking up. She admitted
“We try to convince the kids to stay in their rooms since there’s
only two of us (on midnight shift monitoring six children) until 9am
when first shift comes in.”
I reviewed the agency’s policy/program statement identifying their
ratio of youth to staff as 2:1 during waking hours. It does not
identify the staffing ratio during sleeping hours or what hours the
facility considers as “waking” and “sleeping.”
7

Analysis While tending to her administrative and supervisory duties, CA left
the residential unit out of ratio on 6/12/23. With intersecting/
overlapping roles, it is impossible for regulators to determine the
facility's daily compliance with their identified staffing ratio.
According to Staff 5, children are expected to stay in their rooms
until the dayshift staff arrive at 9am in order to meet the 2:1
staffing pattern. This seems punitive to the children and led to an
altercation between staff and a child in SIR 2023C0000544. Also
without designated waking and sleeping hours, it is impossible for
regulators to determine the facility’s daily compliance with their
stated ratio.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The American Academy of Pediatrics’ recommended amount of
sleep for ages 6 – 12 is 9 to 12 hours and for ages 13 – 17 is 8 to
10 hours. The facility must designate “normal sleeping hours” as
required in the rules and staff per their day time ratio during
waking hours.
CONSULTATION
Adrian Group Home accepts male and females ages 6 – 17 and
has one living space for ten youth. This age range may be too
broad for one living space. For supervision and programming
purposes, I recommended the age range be narrowed to a five- or
six-year span.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Rule Code & Rule 400.4130 Privacy and confidentiality.
Section (1) An institution shall assure resident and parent privacy and
Description confidentiality and shall protect residents from exploitation.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Additional Staff 4 shared youth names with Complainant which violates
Finding confidentiality.
Investigation When Complainant who does not work at the facility reported to
the government agency, he identified the first and last names of
the children who were allegedly abused by staff. Complainant
said he received the information from Staff 4.
8

Analysis Staff 4 violated confidentiality by sharing the children’s identifying
data with Complainant.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and a corrective action plan is required. Per the
recommendation in special investigation 2023C0000500, a First Provisional license
is recommended.
